channel.title: Noisy analogue input
channel.description:
Hi there, I tried several analogue inputs and all of them are very noisy. My config is just a simple pot (extreme pins go to VDD and ground, and central pin goes to analogue input). The result is extremly noisy. Do I need to insert a caps in somewhere or else ? on another hand is it possible to display the 12bit datas, the analogue object is blue and only permits display of 7 bit...
Thanks

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @borututuforte
item.description:
@borututuforte wrote:

I'll try that, thanks a lot!

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @lokki
item.description:
@lokki wrote:

yep, looks good. you can also solder the capacitor across the potentiometer, from ground to middle pin. or directly from the axo input to ground. it depends a little on how long those wires from potentiometer to analog in are going to be. i would say, try on the pot first(easiest), if you still have too much noise, move them closer to the board.

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @borututuforte
item.description:
@borututuforte wrote:

Thanks. Just to make sure that I don't screw this up I made a sketch of how I would do the wiring:

sketch2.png842x595 296 KB

Would it work like that?

Also what kind of capacitors do I need - are these ok (10nF ceramic capacitors with 50V rating)?

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @lokki
item.description:
@lokki wrote:

no you want one capacitor from every analog in you use

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @borututuforte
item.description:
@borututuforte wrote:

Hi, I'm digging out this old thread as I was looking for ways to reduce potentiometer noise before I finally start building an enclosure for my axoloti. It's going to be out of wood, so I'm going to shield it with copper tape on the inside like described in this thread.

To further reduce noise, how important is adding capacitors?

johannes:

A 10nF capacitor between GND and the analog input could reduce noise.

I also don't really get this - would I solder a wire from the center pin of a potentiometer to an analog input and then another wire from the input to the capacitor, then to GND?
Could only one capacitor be used for all of my 15 potentiometers?

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @johannes johannes
item.description:
@johannes wrote:

kashis:

it is quite important because i control the dial matrix with them,and everytime i switch to another carrier what i want to modulate,he automaticly goes to the value what i had before,just because he wiggles a tiny tiny bit.

I believe excessive noise is not your problem here, but the dial matrix reacting on every tiny change. Please start a different topic (or reply to an existing topic if it exists) about this dial matrix business.

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @kashis dennis
item.description:
@kashis wrote:

im having th same problem,

im using:

  • 10 x 10 K linear pots
  • all is grounded
  • 2 switches (on ground ,before vdda,no differnce)
  • 4 rotary switches,only 2 really connected with the resistor chain,2 are connected to ground,vdda and gpio(before not connected ,no difference)
  • there is nothing disconnected
  • everyhing is on VDDA

it is quite important because i control the dial matrix with them,and everytime i switch to another carrier what i want to modulate,he automaticly goes to the value what i had before,just because he wiggles a tiny tiny bit.

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @berzelius
item.description:
@berzelius wrote:

That was it, I grounded all the other inputs.
Now it works great
Fantastic !!

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @kinetiq
item.description:
@kinetiq wrote:

Have you tried grounding the adjacent analog input pins? All those unused traces / terminals can sometimes act as antennas that pick up more noise.

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @berzelius
item.description:
@berzelius wrote:

It's getting better now ! I just soldered the capacitor directly on the axoloti, and I use a kfilter object to smooth everything.

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @berzelius
item.description:
@berzelius wrote:

OK, in a last attempt I just changed the cables. And it's much better !!!
I still have a little noise which make the sine wave a little grainy. Capacitors between input and ground make it worse. Maybe it is possible to smooth it with an object ?
Nevertheless when pot is at max value , there is noise, as much as before, but only when it reaches the last degrees of rotation.
Thanks for your patience

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @berzelius
item.description:
@berzelius wrote:

The voltage readouts are stable. I changed to osc/sine but it's still noisy the same way.
Yes in my example it was a log potentiometer, I but tested with linear pot, and brand new. log or linear still the same.

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @johannes johannes
item.description:
@johannes wrote:

How noisy are the voltage readouts in the main Axoloti window (5V and VDD)?
I suggest to use "osc/sine", not "osc/sine lin" for better mapping, using "osc/sine lin" (and a linear potentiometer rather than a logarithmic one, I suspect you're using a log potentiometer from your screenshot) I do get noises too, that's because the resolution of the analog input is not used efficiently that way.

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @berzelius
item.description:
@berzelius wrote:

The noise on input is about 2 units.
I tried on all analogue inputs from PA0 to PC4 but still the same problem. When I look at help object it shows movement on PA4 PA5 PA6 PA7 PB0 PB1 PC0 PC1 (when physicaly conected to PA4). All are noisy.
Here are the screenshot, without touching and full rotation:

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @johannes johannes
item.description:
@johannes wrote:

I observe 0.03 units noise from a gpio/in/analog on a disp/p.
I don't hear objectionable pitch noise when connecting gpio/in/analog to osc/sine...
Are you sure you have selected the right input in the gpio/in/analog object? Because the next input channels will also follow the previous one if they're not connected to a source (but in a noisy way).

If you create a gpio/in/analog object and choose help from the object popup menu, (or menu help->library->gpio->in->analog), that patch shows all analog channels at once.

Maybe post screenshots of a gpio/in/analog connected to disp/chart p, one without touching the potentiometer, another showing the full range of rotation of the potentiometer?

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @berzelius
item.description:
@berzelius wrote:

Hi,
Just to make sure if it was from my setup or material: I unsoldered everything and just measured voltage with multimeter. Between Ground and vdda it's 3.24 V, but between ground and PA4 (or any other output pin) it's noisy.
By the way PA4 in output mode works fine. Don't understand why it works on output mode and not on input..

Read full topic

item.title: Noisy analogue input
item.dc:creator: @johannes johannes
item.description:
@johannes wrote:

The way you put cables in the solder holes is probably not making good contact.
I suggest to solder a female header in the gpio solder holes if you want to plug in prototyping cables.
The reason there is no female header pre-assembled is that there are many different options: board-to-wire connectors, screw terminals, male headers, female headers, and it's much easier to solder a connector than to desolder one.

Read full topic
